title: How to Clean Your Gold Jewelry Safely & Effectively

steps.title: Fill a bowl with warm water and a few drops of dish soap.
steps.content: Fill a bowl with warm water and a few drops of dish soap. It’s best to use a small bowl instead of cleaning your gold jewelry in the sink, so you don’t risk losing it down the drain. Fill the bowl with lukewarm tap water, then add in a few drops of regular dish soap and stir the solution together, explains master gemologist appraiser Kennon Young. [1] X Expert Source Kennon Young Master Gemologist Appraiser Expert Interview. 11 September 2019. This method works for cleaning gold-plated jewelry, solid gold jewelry, and gold jewelry with gemstones. If your jewelry has gemstones, check to make sure none of them are loose before cleaning. [2] X Research source If any of the gemstones seem wiggly, don’t try to clean the jewelry on your own—take it to a professional jeweler to be repaired and polished.

steps.title: Soak your jewelry for 15–20 minutes in the soapy water.
steps.content: Soak your jewelry for 15–20 minutes in the soapy water. Leave your jewelry in the solution to break apart dirt and grime that has accumulated on the surface. Soaking your jewelry also helps remove debris and residue that’s stuck inside crevices or underneath gemstones. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub the jewelry with a soft-bristled toothbrush to break apart grime.
steps.content: Scrub the jewelry with a soft-bristled toothbrush to break apart grime. Young specifically suggests using a baby toothbrush since they’re very gentle on the gemstones and the metal, but any soft-bristled toothbrush will work. [4] X Expert Source Kennon Young Master Gemologist Appraiser Expert Interview. 11 September 2019. Dip the bristles of the toothbrush into the soapy water and gently scrub the surface of your jewelry, focusing on any tight nooks and crannies where dirt, oils, and debris may get caught. If you’re cleaning gold rings or earrings with gemstones, scrub the underside of the stones to help restore their shine and sparkle.

steps.title: Rinse your jewelry with warm water.
steps.content: Rinse your jewelry with warm water. After you remove all of the dirt and grime from the gold’s surface, dip it into a bowl filled with hot water to rinse off any residual soap or dirt. Swish the jewelry around in the water and gently shake off the excess when you’re finished. [5] X Research source Avoid rinsing your jewelry under running water from your faucet because you could easily lose your grip and drop an expensive piece down the drain. If you need to use your sink, plug the drain or put your jewelry in a fine-mesh strainer to keep it from getting lost.

steps.title: Dry your gold jewelry with a lint-free microfiber cloth.
steps.content: Dry your gold jewelry with a lint-free microfiber cloth. “What people don’t realize is that gold scratches extremely easily,” says jewelry professional Nicole Wegman. In fact, gold is so soft that a paper towel is actually abrasive enough to scratch it, she explains. [6] X Expert Source Nicole Wegman Jewelry Professional & Founder of Ring Concierge Expert Interview. 23 April 2020. To avoid damaging your jewelry, use a soft microfiber cloth or an old T-shirt to gently pat it dry, and avoid using paper towels or tissues. Once your jewelry is dry, it’s ready to wear or be put away in a safe place. [7] X Expert Source Nicole Wegman Jewelry Professional & Founder of Ring Concierge Expert Interview. 23 April 2020.

steps.title: Commercial gold cleaner is a great alternative to dish soap.
steps.content: Commercial gold cleaner is a great alternative to dish soap. “I recommend cleaning weekly with any jewelry cleaner—it’s safe on diamonds and gold,” Wegner says. “You want to soak it [in the jewelry cleaner] for a few minutes, and then you want to scrub it with the little brush that often comes with the jewelry cleaner. If you don’t have one, you can just use a soft toothbrush and then rinse it under warm water.” [8] X Expert Source Nicole Wegman Jewelry Professional & Founder of Ring Concierge Expert Interview. 23 April 2020. There are a few different commercial gold cleaners on the market, so be sure to follow the instructions listed on the specific product you buy.

steps.title: Diluted ammonia works as well, but only for jewelry without soft gems.
steps.content: Diluted ammonia works as well, but only for jewelry without soft gems. If your gold jewelry is free of any soft gems, you can clean it in a 1:6 ratio of ammonia and water, using a soft toothbrush to clear away any grime as needed. Rinse off the jewelry and blot it dry with a gentle cloth, and that’s it! [9] X Research source Ammonia can damage amber, pearl, and opal and is also harmful to high-porosity stones (e.g., turquoise), so if your jewelry contains these gems, avoid this cleaning method. [10] X Research source Stick to water and dish soap, instead.

steps.title: Vinegar
steps.content: Vinegar You may have heard some people recommending vinegar as a cleaning solution for gold, but graduate gemologist Edward Lewand actually cautions against this. He recommends sticking to a solution of Dawn dish soap for cleaning your gold jewelry at home, or taking it to a professional to be polished. [11] X Expert Source Edward Lewand Graduate Gemologist & Accredited Appraiser Expert Interview. 6 August 2019.

steps.title: Toothpaste or baking soda
steps.content: Toothpaste or baking soda Gold can scratch very easily, so abrasive agents like toothpaste and baking soda can do more harm than good when it comes to regular jewelry maintenance. [12] X Research source “You don’t want to use toothpaste,” says Lewand. “Again, some mild dish detergent like Dawn is perfectly fine, and a toothbrush. That’ll pretty much clean it.” [13] X Expert Source Edward Lewand Graduate Gemologist & Accredited Appraiser Expert Interview. 6 August 2019.

steps.title: Harsh cleaners like chlorine bleach
steps.content: Harsh cleaners like chlorine bleach Using harsh substances like chlorine bleach or acetone to clean your gold jewelry could damage the metal. [14] X Trustworthy Source Gemological Institute of America Nonprofit institute responsible for gemological research and education and setting gemstone buying and selling standards Go to source These cleaning agents could also damage any gemstones that might be inlaid in your jewelry. As a result, it’s usually best to stick with gentler cleaning agents like dish soap, or products specifically formulated for cleaning jewelry, like commercial gold cleaner.

steps.title: Wipe your jewelry off with a microfiber cloth after each time you wear it.
steps.content: Wipe your jewelry off with a microfiber cloth after each time you wear it. Because oils from your skin or any lotions you’re wearing may get on your jewelry, it’s a good idea to wipe the pieces off with a soft, damp cloth whenever you take the pieces off for the day. [15] X Research source This prevents gunk from building up on your jewelry and keeps it looking bright and shiny. Make sure to only wipe your gold jewelry off with soft, non-abrasive materials, like a microfiber cloth or an old T-shirt. Don’t use rougher materials like paper towels, as they can leave scratches.

steps.title: Do routine cleanings once a month to maintain your jewelry.
steps.content: Do routine cleanings once a month to maintain your jewelry. If you notice your jewelry looks visibly dull or dingy, carve out a few minutes in your schedule each month to soak and scrub the pieces clean. Cleaning your gold jewelry on a monthly basis helps prevent the buildup of dirt and oils, so your jewelry continues to sparkle and shine. [16] X Research source If you wear your gold jewelry more frequently, you may need to clean it twice a month to keep it looking brand new.

steps.title: Take your gold to a jeweler for professional cleaning once a year.
steps.content: Take your gold to a jeweler for professional cleaning once a year. Graduate gemologist and jeweler Mark Sandler recommends taking your jewelry in to be professionally cleaned and polished on a yearly basis. [17] X Expert Source Mark Sandler Graduate Gemologist, Jeweler, & Appraiser Expert Interview. 5 November 2019. First, contact the jeweler you purchased your gold jewelry from and see if they offer free cleaning or polishing services. Otherwise, search for jewelers in your area and ask how much they charge for cleaning. Some jewelers may offer free cleanings, but it will normally cost between $25–50 USD. A jeweler will be able to clean your jewelry safely, so you don’t have to worry about it getting damaged in the process. They may also be able to remove scratches from the surface of your jewelry.

steps.title: Take off your jewelry before doing strenuous or messy activities.
steps.content: Take off your jewelry before doing strenuous or messy activities. If you plan on exercising, swimming, doing household chores, or any activity that could get dirty, remove your jewelry to prevent damage. You should also take off gold jewelry whenever you’re applying sunscreen or lotion, or if you’re taking a shower, as these things can make the metal look dull or dingy. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Examine your jewelry for damage before wearing it.
steps.content: Examine your jewelry for damage before wearing it. Before you put on your jewelry, check that the clasps are secure and undamaged, so they don’t break throughout the day. If you have gold jewelry that contains gemstones, look at the stones to make sure they’re not loose or wobbly. If you notice any damage or loose gems, take your jewelry to a professional for repairs. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Store your gold in a jewelry box or tarnish-resistant pouch.
steps.content: Store your gold in a jewelry box or tarnish-resistant pouch . Whenever you’re not wearing your jewelry, place it inside a protective box or pouch to keep it free from dust and dirt. Lined boxes or pouches also prevent the jewelry from getting scratched or damaged if they’re jostled around, so they’re perfect for making your gold pieces last. [20] X Research source Avoid stacking gold jewelry on top of each other because they could chip or scratch one another.

steps.title: When should you take your gold jewelry to a professional?
steps.content: When should you take your gold jewelry to a professional? Sandler recommends taking your gold jewelry in for a professional cleaning by a jeweler once per year. [21] X Expert Source Mark Sandler Graduate Gemologist, Jeweler, & Appraiser Expert Interview. 5 November 2019. Additionally, if you notice any damage or loose gemstones on your jewelry, you should let a professional do the cleaning rather than trying to tackle it yourself, to avoid damaging the piece any further.

steps.title: What do “karats” mean with gold jewelry?
steps.content: What do “karats” mean with gold jewelry? Gold is a pretty soft and malleable metal, so it’s not very durable on its own. As a result, gold jewelry is often made of a mixture of gold and other stronger metals (called alloys). The purity of a piece of gold jewelry is then measured in karats. For example, if your gold jewelry is made out of 18 parts pure gold and 6 parts other metal alloys, it’s 18-karat gold. If your jewelry is made out of 100% pure gold and no metal alloys, it is 24-karat gold. [22] X Research source Although they sound similar, a “karat” is not the same thing as a “carat.” A carat (spelled with a “C”) is a unit of weight used to measure gemstones like diamonds. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Does gold jewelry tarnish?
steps.content: Does gold jewelry tarnish? “Gold itself doesn’t tarnish, but the alloys in the gold will tarnish,” explains Lewand. “Sometimes they’ll use silver, sometimes they’ll use nickel, sometimes they’ll use copper—it all depends on the color they’re going for. So that’s actually what’s tarnishing the gold. If for some reason your [pure] gold piece does tarnish, you’d have to take it to a real professional jewelry store and have it cleaned and polished.” [24] X Expert Source Edward Lewand Graduate Gemologist & Accredited Appraiser Expert Interview. 6 August 2019.
